title: What is literature and its scope? - Quora

response.answer_text: Literature, in its broadest sense, is any single body of written works. More restrictively, it is writing considered as an art form, or any single writing deemed to have artistic or intellectual value, often due to deploying language in ways that differ from ordinary usage. Its Latin root literatura/litteratura (derived itself from littera: letter or handwriting) was used to refer to all written accounts, though contemporary definitions extend the term to include texts that are spoken or sung (oral literature). Literature can be classified according to whether it is fiction or non-fiction and whether it is poetry or prose; it can be further distinguished according to major forms such as the novel, short story or drama; and works are often categorized according to historical periods or their adherence to certain aesthetic features or expectations (genre). The concept has changed meaning over time: nowadays it can broaden to include non-written verbal art forms, and thus it is difficult to agree on its origin, which can be paired with that of language or writing itself. Developments in print technology have allowed an evergrowing distribution and proliferation of written works, culminating in electronic literature. Literature is a basic subject in the Humanities that helps you to get a foundation in other disciplines like history, politics, psychology, philosophy, economics, etc. Studying literature helps you to get insight into culture, human nature, languages and communication, and gives you better interpersonal skills and soft skills. With basic Literature education and some advanced specialization, you can be a teacher, trainer, counselor, public relations officer, creative writer, content writer, journalist, translator, librarian, proofreader, editor, digital marketer, entrepreneur, compere, event manager, tourist guide, interpreter, and so on. Many high profile politicians, lawyers, businessmen, world class trainers, famous authors, etc are literature graduates or postgraduates. It's indeed rewarding to study literature.

It depends a lot on what you mean by ‘scope’. If you are speaking in terms of job opportunities, studying Literature at the Undergraduate level opens up various job profiles: as a content writer, a journalist, an editor, a professor, or even more diffuse options like marketing and Human Resources. The study of Literature makes you a more empathetic and analytical person, and I think that’s the greatest asset of them all. :)
